text: Can at North River. Pours a hazed amber apricot gold with a medium sized white head. Fruity citrus, creamy wheat and soft melon. Slow citrus, soft wheat, musk. Tasty.

16 oz can I got in a trade as an extra. The pour is a golden orange color with a thinner light tan head and a couple spots of soapy lace as it falls down. The aroma is pretty decent. There is a light hoppiness and a little bit of juiciness to it. Its actually like a juicy IPA without a lot of the dryness and bitterness. They hit a nice balance here. The flavornis much of the same. Its got a bit of maltiness right up front and a hint of sweeter hops. Its a nice balance. The flavor is really what sets it apart from an IPA. The mouth feel is lighter and definitely creamy with a softer carbonation and a lingeringly malty and light hop finish. This is really well balanced and distinguishes itself. I like it.
Can. Pours quite hazy orange, small off white head, decent lacing. Aroma is pine and grapefruit zest. Flavor is medium sweet, medium bitter. Medium body. Basically a sweet DIPA. Cream ale my ass.
Can: Poured golden with white head. Aroma is very fruity tropical nose. Taste is more hops fruity a little smooth creamy finish.

Poured from 16 oz can given to me by Maxbier. Pours golden with white head . Aroma is tropical fruit and citrus. Flavor is tropical fruit and citrus with grapefruit finish. Big thanks to Maxbier for sharing.
Can thx to Gorgone. Pours slightly hazy orange gold, thin scattered white head. Aroma is citrus, mango, papaya, pine, grass. Flavor is gooey citrus, mango, light caramel, bread, med sweet.

2015 BJCP Category: 34C Experimental Ale (base brew: 22A Double IPA)
AROMA: Hop-forward aroma of orange, though sweet like sherbet. Some light yeast esters. 10/12APPEARANCE: Basketball orange hue. Body is very cloudy with occasional CO2 bubble floating by. Large, white, frothy head which retains and laces well. 3/3FLAVOR: Described as a "hoppy imperial cream ale," this more closely resembles a DIPA. Hop-forward throughout with a strong orange taste. Bitterness is pretty high, too. Body has a sturdy malt backbone, though not especially sweet or any malt distinctiveness. No hop bite, just a general high IBU sensation (~70?). No corn nor lager-like flavor whatsoever which makes me scoff at the cream ale marketing. 16/20MOUTHFEEL: Medium-full body with a noticeable viscosity - leaves me feeling full. Texture is velvety smooth as if it were on nitro. Alcohol warmth and taste is present, but complementary. Hops linger, but are not biting or harsh. 5/5OVERALL IMPRESSION: This is probably best considered a DIPA. It completely fails as a "cream ale" by any measure. Tasty and fun to drink. 8/10TOTAL SCORE: 42/50DISCLAIMER: The author is not a certified BJCP judge; therefore, this score sheet is not necessarily indicative of proper BJCP judging techniques and protocol. The author is grading to 2015 BJCP Guidelines in order to prepare for examination.

Can shared by Kyle, thanks! Pours a near clear yellow gold with a white head that dissipates slowly to the edges and laces. Aroma has a strong sweet grain, biscuit and cookie note with some bitter pine supporting. Flavor starts sweet with grains and biscuit with some bitter pine in the finish.

Pour from a 16oz can. Hazy yellow orange wig big off white head. Light grassy hop aroma. A big punch of flavors up front: orange peel, citrus, grassy pine, hints of caramel sweetness. Finish has pleasant creamy malt and citrus bitter.

Tasted from can. Pours a murky gold with a nice white head. Aroma has some citrus notes of pineapple with caramel and sweet bready notes. Taste is well balanced and really tastes like an IPA. No way I would know this is a cream. Flavors of citrus fruit, caramel, molasses, pine on the finish. Chewy mouthfeel. Incredible cream. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Opens with a high hiss. Nose is sweet honey. Light pils malt. Taste is a diabetic sugar bomb of alcohol. Not good

Aroma: Cream, Crackers, Mildly Malty...
Appearance: Hazy Golden Straw Hue, Passes Some Light, Thin White Head Ring, Sticky Lacing....
Taste: Cream, Malty, Bittering Hops...
Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying

Amber honey gold thin white head; aroma is sweet notes of pineapple a touch hops; flava is sweet fruity pineapple with hop bitterness; feels medium tight fizzy zing; finishes tangy malty with moderate bitter hop notes

Can at Cannibal Gotham Market. Murky golden orange with a thick, creamy beige head and heavy lace. Boozy and doughy aroma, vanilla cake, some astringent hops, pine, and citrus. Finishes heavy bitter and pretty dry. Strong, boozy mouthfeel, average carbonation. Lots going on here, but it is pretty tasty.
Can. Hazy orange yellow pour, with a white head. Sweet grain, stale bread, bitter citrus peel, grass, kind of sugary, and alcohol. Not great.
16 ounce can. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. A big fruity sugary nose. Big rich sugary malts, tastes like a barley wine, fresh fruity hops, caramel. Big berries. Quite nice.
Amber orange colored pour. Small white head. Little bit of lacing. Aroma of tangerine. Taste is corn, hops, citrus. Bitter finish.

Can from Cannibal West; shared with Linh and Ken. Pours a dirty amber gold with thick white lace. Nose is alcohol and grains - a bit off-putting. Mouthfeel is pretty abrasive - lots of alcohol, dirty grains, malt and thick sugar.

Nice piney aroma with notes of orange and tropical aromatics. Appearance is a hazy yellow gold with a good head retention. Flavor has plenty of hop flavors with the pine notes sticking out the most. Malt is sweet on the end with notes of cracker and biscuit. Mouthfeel is medium high with a medium level of carbonation. Overall, the beer has a great hop bouquet. I would have liked some of the citrus, tropical notes to come through more on the flavor. The beer's body would be better if it was lighter. Overall, it's a good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This was flipping awesome. Pours super hazy unfiltered orange. Taste is super creamy with amazing citrus hop bite. Orange fruit mango grapefruit boozy rine. Everything good comes out in this one. It's juicy creamy hoppy. A+++

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16oz can. Pours a hazy amber color with a small foamy white head. Aroma of fresh grapefruit, orange, sweet malts, and some light tropical fruit in the finish. Taste of old oranges, grass, grain, herbal tea, caramel malts, and citrus and pine bitterness.
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2016 Can, pours hazy golden with medium to large off white head. Smell is nice with pine and orange hops. Flavor is booze and a touch of cream. Light to medium body. Finish is harsh
Can - pours yellow white head - nose/taste of angel food cake, pine, hoppy citrus and creamy malt - med body

can poured into a tulip glass..hazy gold with a fluffy white head..aroma of
pine,resin,tropical fruits,caramel..tastes of all the previous with some floral
notes..medium bodied..excellent.

Drank from a pint glass, poured from a large can, split amongst three. Pours a nice clear, almost copper color, with nice head retention. Bit too much hop aroma for a cream ale. An alright brew, as per usual, overly hopped by Carton.

16 ounce can. Pours a hazy orange gold color. Firm creamy white head with nice lacing. Big resiny hop nose. First sip brings a creamy mouthfeel and intensely bitter hop blast off. As the bitterness subsides, there is a bready, caramel maltiness that emerges. Farther along comes a rush of dank citrus hoppiness and warming alcohol. This is a complex, layered brew that really needs to be sipped slowly to reveal the many nuances. This aint no Genny Cream Ale. Excellent! A bit pricy at 18 bucks for four 16 ounce cans.
Can. Orange pour with tan head. Sweet citrus, herbal, malty aromas. Flavors are sweet, herbal, grassy hops, boozy tones.

Tallboy expensive ass can via a 4-pack from Spirits Brick. Poured a chunky, lightly hazed, deep rusty gold with a foamy white head. Aroma/flavor of yeast, old bread, stale tea, dry citrus. Aroma has some light fruit notes and pineapple rind also. Body has noticeable heat throughout, average carbonation, a big chewy mouthfeel and is just harsh in general. Definitely not worth the ridiculous $20.32 I spent on the 4-pack.
